MPUC Docket No. E015/M-24-383  
Dear Judge McKenzie: 
On behalf of ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power, as well as Canada Pension 
Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”), 
attached please find the Response Testimonies to Hearing Exhibit OAG-412 of the 
following witnesses: 
 Jennifer J. Cady  
 Jonathan Bram 
The information designated within each Response Testimony as highly 
confidential trade secret has been designated as nonpublic because it contains 
information the Company considers to be trade secret as defined by Minn. Stat. § 13.37, 
subd. 1(b). The information derives independent economic value from not being generally 
known to, or readily ascertainable by proper means by, others who could obtain economic 
advantage from its disclosure or use and the Company maintains these materials as trade 
secret pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 13.37, subd. 1(b). Additional information supporting the 
trade secret nature of this data is available in the underlying document, Hearing Exhibit 
OAG-412. 
  
 
   
 Please contact us if you have any questions. 
 
Elizabeth M. Brama

Q. You explained that these are assumptions in GIP’s valuation model . Please explain 13 
what that model is and how it is used.  14 
A. It is not possible to know with certainty how an investment like the Partners’ acquisition 15 
of ALLETE will develop over time or what return GIP or its investors will receive from 16 
an investment. We conduct diligence to understand potential investments as best as we 17 
can, but there are inevitably things we will not know before they occur.  In order to 18 
evaluate a potential investment, we have to make assumptions about certain facts and 19 
trends and consider a variety of possible scenarios, including the future performance of 20 
the company.  We then model the effect of different scenarios to understand how our 21 
investment could be affected if those scenarios occur.  Those scenarios are not 22 
necessarily situations or things we think will happen or want to happen, but they are 23 
scenarios we need to consider to fully evaluate the investment. We then take the outputs 24 
of that model and include some of those in documents like the presentation in Hearing 25 
Exhibit OAG -412 to demonstrate potential (but not guaranteed) investment outcomes, 26 
including both “upside” and “downside” cases.  27

Q. Please state your name , employer, and position . 2 
A. My name is Jennifer J. Cady, I am employed by ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power13 
as Vice President of Regulatory and Legislative Affairs. 4

2025. 17

A. I am providing Response Testimony to certain portions of Hearing Exhibit OAG -412, 20 
as permitted by the Administrative Law Judge by oral ruling made on April 3, 2025 , on 21 
behalf of Minnesota Power. Global Infrastructure Partners’ (“GIP”) witness Jonathan 22 
Bram provides GIP’s perspective and additional information. 23

Q. Are you sponsoring any exhibits in this proceeding? 25 
A. No. 26 
27 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Surrebuttal  Testimony and 
the Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise 
specifically defined, references to “ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including 
Minnesota Power and all re gulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to 
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  

2 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339

Cady Response  II. RESPONSE TO HEARING EXHIBIT OAG -412 1 
Q. What  is Hearing Exhibit OAG -412? 2 
A. Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 is  the narrative and an attachment to GIP’s  third 3 
supplemental response to the Department of Commerce (“DOC”) information request 4 
0012 (“DOC IR 0012 Supp 3 HCTS ”) served in this proceeding. 5 
6 
Q. Have you seen this document before? 7 
A. Yes. I, along with other senior executives at the Company have access to highly 8 
confidential trade secret (“ HCTS ”) information that is not available to all of ALLETE, 9 
and I reviewed it during the discovery process in this proceeding. 10 
11 
Q. Was any response to DOC IR 0012 previously in the record? 12 
A. Yes. The Office of the Attorney General – Residential Utilities Division (“OAG -RUD”) 13 
had included DOC IR 001 2.02 Attach SUPP HCTS with the Direct Testimony of its 14 
witness, Brian P. Lebens, at Schedule BPL -D-8 (“BPL -D-8") (Hearing Exhibit OAG - 15 
401). At the evidentiary hearing, on April 3, 2025, the OAG -RUD moved DOC IR 16 
0012.02 Attach Supp 3 HCTS for admission (with the cover narrative , as discussed 17 
below ) as Hearing Exhibit OAG -412. 18 
19 
From a timing perspective, t he attachment to GIP’s response to DOC IR 0012 that 20 
became BPL -D-8 was served on the OAG -RUD on October 9, 2024.2 Hearing Exhibit 21 
OAG -412 was served on the OAG -RUD on January 18, 2025, but was not attached to 22 
any pre -filed document in the case. BPL -D-8 was included with Witness Lebens’ Direct 23 
Testimony, filed on February 4, 2025. The OAG did not file an errata or seek to 24 
introduce what was ultimately marked as Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 until the last day 25 
of the evidentiary hearing (April 3, 2025) after the Company’s witnesses had completed 26 
their live testimony and all parties waived questions for the Partners.  27 
28 
2 On October 9, 2024, GIP responded to OAG -RUD IR 0003, which requested copies of the responses to all other 
Parties’ information requests in this proceeding. OAG -RUD access to information request responses provided by 
Minnesota Power, Canada Pension Plan I nvestment Board, and GIP was granted contemporaneously with that 
response.  

3 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Response  Q. How do BPL -D-8 and  Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 differ?  1 
A. BPL-D-8 is an earlier version of  GIP’s response to DOC IR 0012 and only includes 2 
DOC IR 0012.02 Attach Supp HCTS. Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 includes a more recent 3 
version of DOC IR 0012 Attach, labeled “DOC IR 0012.02 Attach Supp 3 HCTS,” 4 
which is the same document as BPL -D-8 except with additional material disclosed . 5 
6 
At the request of the Company and the Partners, Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 also includes 7 
the narrative cover pages for GIP’s response to DOC IR 0012, which included  context 8 
that is important for Hearing Exhibit OAG -412, but which  was not included with any 9 
witness’s testimony.  10 
11 
Q. Why does it matter to the Company that the new material in Hearing Exhibit OAG - 12 
412 was added to the record on the last day of the evidentiary hearing? 13 
A. Because Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 was entered  into the record at the hearing through 14 
Witness Lebens,  the Company did not previously have  an opportunity to address the 15 
information included in Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 that was not included in BPL -D-8, 16 
found in Hearing Exhibit OAG -401. Several aspects of the new material are incorrect 17 
with respect to the Company, could negatively affect the Company if misperceived, and 18 
need context that neither the Company nor GIP had an opportunity to provide outside of 19 
this Response Testimony . 20 
21 
Q. Why was it important to provide context about the new information included in 22 
Hearing Exhibit OAG -412? 23 
A. As part of this Acquisition and regulatory process, ALLETE executive leadership has 24 
long understood that the Partners have explored  various scenarios  and made 25 
assumption s or advanced hypothetical s in the course of evaluating bidding on and 26 
ultimately negotiating an Acquisition of ALLETE , as is a normal matter of course in 27 
complex business transactions , and that some of those assumptions are simply incorrect . 28 
As the deal matured and the Partners had further opportunity to get to  know the 29 
Company, it became clear that several items in the material added to this record through 30 
Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 are examples of just such issues. While it is important to note 31 

4 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198

out to be correct or incorrect , the Company is concerned that the information OAG - 2 
RUD  seeks to add at the end of the evidence -taking process is not only incorrect in some 3 
ways I describe here but also harmful to the Company now or in the future if taken as 4 
accurate or predictions rather than GIP’s scenario runs. 5 
6 
Q. Please explain what you mean , specifically,  by this additional material being 7 
incorrect  or needing context ? 8 
A. There are several issues of importance to the Company . It is important to understand 9 
that, i n DOC IR 0012.02 Attach Supp 3 HCTS : 10

Q. Is there additional context that is necessary to properly consider the material 8 
within Hearing Exhibit OAG -412?  9 
A. Yes. As part of any complex business transaction, scenario planning is an expected and 10 
routine part of the evaluation and due diligence process. The information contained in 11 
Hearing Exhibit OAG -412 was developed by GI P without the input of the Company 12 
and reflected what GIP knew of Minnesota Power at the time of its creation in 2023. 13 
GIP conducted an extensive due diligence  process that provided it with more 14 
information about the Company’s strategies and Minnesota regulation in the time that 15 
elapsed after the date of this presentation , and nonetheless disclosed early data even 16 
though it can be misconstrued by intervening parties.  The contents of GIP’s 2023 17 
internal scenario planning conducted  as a result of early evaluation processes does not 18 
reflect GIP’s current view or Minnesota Power’s strategy today , as discussed in the 19 
Response Testimony of Witness Bram .  20 
 21

As someone who lives and works in this community, I support the acquisition of
Minnesota Power by GIP and CPP. This change offers a real opportunity to improve our energy system—making itmore reliable, efficient, and ready for the future. Meeting state energy goals willrequire investment, and this deal helps us get there. Labor unions, business leaders, and experts who understand our power systemare backing this move. Their support shows that this plan is solid and focused onlong-term stability. Some have raised concerns about rates, but the same regulators will still overseepricing. This acquisition will help fund critical infrastructure upgrades andsupport cost-effective energy solutions over time.Our workforce is key to delivering power safely and reliably. This transition keepsskilled professionals in place and supports the jobs that keep our energy gridrunning. There’s been some misinformation out there, but the facts are clear: regulatoryoversight stays in place, and commitments to renewable energy remain strong. No plan is without risk, but this one is smart, structured, and built for the longterm. It strengthens our energy system, supports working people, and benefitsthe communities we live in. I urge leaders to approve this acquisition.
P.S. I appreciate the diligent and informative presentation on the proposed
acquisition given at the Duluth City Council Meeting on March 24, 2025.
-Brandon Shofner
Duluth, MN

No plan is without risk, but this one is smart, structured, and built for the longterm. It strengthens our energy system, supports working people, and benefitsthe communities we live in. I urge leaders to approve this acquisition. Derek PedersonProctor, MN

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Katherine Hinson
Gilbert, AZ 85295-7212
angelfishhinson@aol.com

As a both a Minnesota Power customer and ALLETE employee for the past 10 years, I support the
acquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments and GIP. Both investment firms have clear track records ofinvesting in and supporting the development of both domestic and global sustainable energyinfrastructure projects. The financial support and expertise of these two firms will be extremelyvaluable to ALLETE and Minnesota Power for the challenging path ahead - to implement thecompany’s strategy and meet the state of Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard. Developing generatingfacilities, acquiring assets, and procuring the energy necessary to meet these goals – all whilemaintaining competitiveness and ensuring a cost-effective product for customers, requiresconsistent financial support on a large scale. 
The result of this transaction with CPP Investments and GIP will be a change in ownership, not a
change in strategy. Minnesota Power will continue to be an investor-owned public utility, locallymanaged, guided by its company values, and will continue to be regulated by the Minnesota PublicUtilities Commission. I appreciate that the company will remain in the communities we serve andcontinue to provide the same support to those communities as we always have. 
I’m excited for the future and appreciate the opportunity to voice my support for the acquisition.

I urge you to support and approve the ALLETE acquisition. Though some fear what this acquisition
may mean, I fear what happens if it does not go through. Minnesota Power is a regulated utility, whodevelops an Integrated Resource Plan (IRP), which establishes the company strategy for the next 15years. The IRP starts with developing strategy which follows federal and state environmentalrequirements, analyzes numerous customer demand scenarios, and determines how to meet theseneeds in the lowest cost manner. This process has considerable stakeholder input and is ultimatelyapproved by the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (MPUC). The rates are reviewed and approvedby the MPUC and have a max return on equity. All capital and operating expenses are routinelyreviewed and approved by the MPUC through the Rate Review process. The transparency andoversight is robust. This regulated process does not change due to this acquisition. What theacquisition will do is ensure alignment between two investors to execute the plans established in theIRP. It establishes a commitment to these plans and is backed by companies who have the capital toinvest. These dollars are then spent in our local community, add to local tax base, and provide localjobs. This acquisition is a win for ALLETE, a win for employees, and most of all for all rate payingcustomers who will achieve the same outcomes at a lower overall cost. I urge decision makers tomake decisions based on fact and not on fear. Thank you for your consideration.

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Anja Hogan
Duluth, MN 55806-1444
hogan.anja@gmail.com

To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Testimony in docket E-015/PA-24-198 Petition for Acquisition of Allete
Date: Monday, April 14, 2025 10:19:46 AM
Attachments: Testimony 4-14-2025 by Buddy Robinson Docket E-015-PA-24-198.pdf
You don't often get email from buddy@citizensfed.org. Learn why this is important
To the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission:
Attached in pdf form is my testimony in the docket E-015/PA-24-198, regarding the
proposed acquisition of Allete.
Buddy Robinson
1506 N. Central Ave., Duluth, MN 55807
Testimony to the MN Public Utilities Commission regarding the  Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners          Docket # E-015/PA-24-198
By:  Buddy Robinson, 1506 N. Central Ave., Duluth, MN  55807              April 14, 2025
   I have been involved, as an advocate for residential customers, in all of MN Power's rate 
cases from 1980 to about 2015, in interventions by the Senior Citizen Coalition of NE MN/MN 
Senior Federation NE/Citizens Federation of NE MN, and as a witness for some interventions 
by the Energy CENTS Coalition.  Currently, I am a board member of the Citizens Utility Board 
of Minnesota, although I am submitting this testimony as a private citizen.
   As a  Duluth citizen and a MN Power customer for over 40 years,I can assert that if the 
acquisition goes through, there will be a strong risk that my and all residential rates will go up, 
more so than without the acquisition.  It is very disturbing that the testimony includes projected 
rate hikes, yet this is deemed “trade secret” and therefore the public cannot see it.  If they want
to keep those future hikes secret from the public, that in itself says something very significant 
and troubling.
   It's also probable that my City taxes and water rates will go up more so than otherwise, since
Duluth uses a great deal of electricity for water pumping.
   The proposed new owners of Allete are Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board and 
Global Infrastructure Partners – which is now owned by BlackRock, the world's largest asset 
manager, with $11.5 trillion in assets.
   Private equity companies are known for pursing high profit rates --- very possibly, higher 
profit rates than what MN Power has usually sought.   Private equity companies have a pattern
of extracting large profits for a while from their acquisitions and then selling them, often in 5 to 
10 years.  BlackRock will certainly want to recover from our rates the $400 million to $1.5 
billion they plan to pay above market value to buy Allete/MP, according to expert testimony.
   Most people are unaware that in the utility regulation system, the profit that is taken in our 
rates is directly proportional to the dollar value of the generating, transmission, distribution, and
other assets. In other words, you multiply the value of these assets times the allowed rate of 
return, and that gives you the total amount of profit they can take from us.  The higher the 
assets, the higher the total profit.  As a result, there is a clear incentive to build the most 
expensive infrastructure possible, because it (almost) automatically translates into bigger 
profits.   We residential households have to pay the cost, because we are what is known as 
captive customers.  This is especially important in the coming years if data centers, with 
enormous electricity needs, get built in MN Power's territory.  The desire to attract data centers
is especially critical for MN Power, since it's largest customers – taconite mines and paper mills
– are in a state of gradual decline.
   In terms of clean energy, the incentive to make things as expensive as they are able to can 
translate into not wanting many customers to own their own sources of distributed electric 
generation or alternative, localized sources, since that means less generating capacity for MP 
to build and less expense for power lines, and therefore less profit.  It can lead to rejecting the 
most cost effective mix of clean energy production and storage that is available, and extending
the use of expensive fossil fuel electric generation, and air-polluting burning of biomass.
   It's also important to note that BlackRock has significant shares in three of  MN Power's  
largest customers: Cleveland Clliffs, US Steel, and Enbridge.  That creates an incentive to shift
costs from the rates of industrial customers onto everyone else.  This is a clear conflict of 
interest, which by itself, should be enough to block the sale of Allete.
   What happens if that shift takes place?  The industrial customers use three-quarters of MN 
Power's electricity.  The other one-quarter is used by all the other customers combined:  
residents, households, and municipalities like Duluth.   That's a three to one ratio.  So, to 
reduce industrial rates by 5%, you have to raise everyone else by 15%.   Reduce the industrial 
rate by 10%, raise the others by 30%.  Reduce the industrial rate by 20%, raise the others by 
60%, etc.
                   
   The more that BlackRock/CPPIB succeeds in raising the overall revenue requirement, the 
greater the pressure will be to shift costs from the industrial class to other customers, 
especially residential ratepayers.   The Large Power class is worried about their rates going up
higher than otherwise, and that's why the Large Power Intervenors formally oppose this 
acquisition.  If Large Power and Large Light & Power rates go up higher than they would 
otherwise, this increases the incentive of the industrial customers to try to shift more of their 
cost to the other customers classes.
    MN Power already says that the industrial customers pay more than their fair share, and so 
some of their cost should be shifted onto us.  They say the industrial customers subsidize the 
cost for residential ratepayers.  But what does MN Power's own report to its stockholders say? 
It says that in 2024, industrial customers paid $153.8 million for 1,780 megawatt-hours.  
Residential customers paid $42.2 million for 276 megawatt-hours.  Do the math, and you see 
that industrial customers pay, overall, 8.6 cents for each kilowatt-hour.  Residential customers 
pay 15.3 cents – almost twice.  Does that look like they are subsidizing us?  Or is it the other 
way around?
   The rate shift issue isn't new.  MN Power and the big industries have been pushing the 
bogus “subsidy” theory for over 40 years, which has never been fully accepted by the PUC.  
It's quite obvious that the taconite mines and paper mills have been the huge cost-causers for 
the vast majority of MN Power's generating capacity.  MN Power's own hydroelectric power by 
itself – a very low cost energy source – generates enough power to supply almost all of the 
needs of the residential class.
    What is new however, if the acquisition goes through, is that MN Power's owners will have 
deeper pockets than before to try to overwhelm the PUC with high priced experts and 
attorneys.   And if they lose at the PUC, they'll have deeper pockets than before to lobby the 
state legislature to get what they want, which is a real danger.
   MN Power says that it needs this acquisition to secure “reliable access to the equity capital 
required to fund the investments needed for the clean energy transition,” as Jennifer Cady 
testified to the PUC.  If that's the case, then why does their new 15-year Integrated Resource 
Plan propose only 500 megawatts of clean energy and storage, yet 1,105 megawatts – 2.2  
times as much -- in new fossil fuel electric generation?  That sounds like one step forward for 
“Energy Forward” and more than two steps back. 
   And, there are no guarantees that BlackRock, with its thousands of investments and all of 
their demands for capital, would choose to provide all the capital needed for MN Power.  For 
example, they might choose to invest more heavily in utilities that have a better prospect than 
MN Power of landing data center customers.  It is possible that MN Power might do better if it 
were to stick with its own publicly traded stock to raise new capital.
    Some proponents of the proposed acquisition state their thanks for MN Power's track record
up to now, including financial donations to local charities and benefits to local government 
entities.   In urging the PUC to approve the acquisition, they seem to be assuming that the 
same decision process for these types of benefits will be in place.  However, that will not be 
the case, since 100% of ownership of MN Power/Allete will be in the hands of BlackRock 
(60%) and CPPIB (40%).  These two entities will have control of 10 of the 13 Board of Director 
seats.
   Previously, MN Power had very good reasons to act as a “good corporate citizen,” especially 
in regard to the City of Duluth.  BlackRock will have very little incentive to follow in that 
tradition.   BlackRock currently owns 13% of MN Power's stock.  Increasing it to a 60% 
ownership stake is a drastically different situation, in terms of who really gets to make 
decisions.
   Unions are also in favor of the acquisition, since they seem to be getting guarantees to honor
their current contracts.  But what guarantees will they have in the future beyond that?   
Construction unions also favor the acquisition.  Their self interest is naturally in decisions to 
build more generation, distribution and storage infrastructure.  However, there is no assurance 
that more of that would happen under the new ownership compared to otherwise.   A  real risk 
is that BlackRock will seek to maximize short term profits – perhaps in part by paring down the 
workforce and deferring maintenance, and then sell off a badly weakened utility.  If that 
happens, it would further hurt the workers and unions along with ratepayers.  It would put 
Minnesota Power in a much worse status than it is in now.
    In sum, there are no good reasons for the acquisition, and a host of reasons against it.

________________________________Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical publicservice- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information about
the company’s finances and business plans
- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).

Dear Commissioners, 
My name is Josh Fetcher, and while I am not currently a Minnesota Power customer, I plan to
move to Duluth in the near future with my partner and make a home in the Northland. That’s why I
feel compelled to speak out against the proposed sale of ALLETE and Minnesota Power to Global
Infrastructure Partners (GIP) and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP), which would
place majority control under BlackRock. 
This transaction raises serious red flags for future ratepayers like myself. Allowing private equity
to take over a public utility means putting profit over people. We’ve seen what happens in places
like Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, where a similar buyout led to skyrocketing electricity rates.
Minnesota Power’s customers shouldn’t be the next case study in what goes wrong when
essential services are turned into investment vehicles. 
Beyond rates, I’m deeply concerned about the loss of transparency. If this acquisition goes
through, ALLETE would no longer be publicly traded, making it harder for regulators and the
public to monitor decisions that impact us all. As someone who values community accountability
and transparency, I do not want to see the energy future of northern Minnesota decided behind
closed doors. 
I’m also worried about the impact on Minnesota’s climate goals. We’re at a critical point in history
where clean energy isn’t just a nice idea—it’s a necessity. Yet this buyout comes with no clear,enforceable commitments to meeting the 100% carbon-free by 2040 law. That’s unacceptable.
Minnesota Power has not shown that it needs this acquisition to meet its goals. And private equity
firms like GIP are known for flipping their investments in just a few years, not sticking around to
serve communities for the long haul. 
Please deny the proposed acquisition . The risks are too high, and the benefits to the public are
unclear at best. 
Sincerely,
Josh Fetcher
Future Duluth Resident | Moving in 2026Currently residing in FL

Dear Commissioners,
My name is Celeste Gutierrez, and while I am not yet a Minnesota Power ratepayer, I plan to
move to Duluth and build a life in the community served by Minnesota Power. That’s why I’m
deeply concerned about the proposed acquisition of ALLETE by Global Infrastructure Partners
(GIP), a private equity firm recently acquired by BlackRock, and the Canada Pension Plan
Investment Board (CPP).
This transaction is not in the public interest , and I urge the Commission to deny the proposed
acquisition  under Docket E-015/PA-24-198.
The risks this deal poses—to affordability, reliability, transparency, and the clean energy transition
—are too great for Minnesota residents and communities to bear. Private equity ownership of a
public utility fundamentally alters its purpose: shifting from public service to shareholder returns.
GIP’s own business model relies on short-term investments, cost-cutting, and maximizing profits.
These motives are incompatible with the long-term, community-centered service that Minnesotans
deserve.
We’ve seen what happens when private equity enters the utility space. In Michigan’s Upper
Peninsula, a similar buyout led to some of the highest electric rates in the continental U.S. . In
Pittsburgh, a private-equity-owned utility failed its customers during a heatwave, providing limitedcommunication and unreliable service. In Kansas, a private equity firm made $215 million in
profits during a deadly winter storm, prompting lawsuits for alleged price gouging.
This is not a model Minnesota should replicate.
Here are just a few of the major concerns I want to highlight:
Transparency & Oversight Loss: Once ALLETE becomes private, it will no longer be
subject to SEC disclosures. The public and regulators will have far less visibility into
financial decisions, conflicts of interest, or long-term plans.
Conflict of Interest Risks: BlackRock, which will effectively control Minnesota Power
through GIP, holds major stakes in some of Minnesota Power’s largest industrial customers
—like U.S. Steel and Enbridge. These ties raise serious concerns about self-dealing, rate-
setting bias, and fairness to residential ratepayers.
Ratepayer Burden & Cost Increases:  The $6.2 billion acquisition price includes a large
premium. CPP and GIP have provided no legally binding commitment to avoid passing
these costs onto ratepayers. In fact, history shows that private equity often increases rates
to recoup such investments.
Carbon-Free Transition Jeopardized:  Minnesota Power’s current resource plan includes
1,100 MW of new fossil gas and no new solar—a step backwards from the state’s 2040
carbon-free goals. There are no guarantees that GIP and CPP will prioritize clean energy or
stick to coal retirement timelines. Their track record offers no reason to believe they will.
Short-Term Ownership & Local Instability:  GIP typically holds investments for just 5 to 7
years. There’s no assurance Minnesota Power will remain locally controlled. Headquartersin Duluth may only remain as long as it benefits GIP, not the community.
Access to Capital Is Not the Issue: ALLETE has not demonstrated difficulty accessing
capital on public markets. In fact, the MN Department of Commerce and the Attorney
General both found no evidence supporting the need for private equity funding. Claiming
capital access as the reason for this acquisition is unfounded and unsubstantiated.
As someone planning to move to Duluth—drawn by its community values, natural beauty, andcommitment to climate resilience—I want to be part of a future where our energy systems are
equitable, clean, transparent, and locally accountable. This deal undermines that future.
The Public Utilities Commission has a duty to protect the public interest. That includes
safeguarding long-term service reliability, affordability, and transparency over short-term financial
gains for outside investors. Please deny this acquisition and help keep Minnesota Power in
service of Minnesotans—not Wall Street.
Sincerely,
Celeste Gutierrez
Future Duluth Resident | Planning to relocate in 2026
Currently residing in FLcelestek@pm.me

publicly if possible.

I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,

Minneapolis, MN 55406-4012

Local control of Minnesota Power is best for ratepayers and the climate.
My name is Eric Enberg, MD and I practice Family Medicine in West Duluth. Thank you for the
opportunity to speak out on this important issue. 
I am very concerned that the proposed private equity buyout of Allete will be both bad for the
poorest people in town - the working class people I serve every day, and for the climate. Here’s why:
While we don’t know exactly how this deal is structured, private equity firms typically put up 50% of
the cash to buy a company but borrow the other half. It becomes the responsibility of the purchasedcompany to not only maintain and indeed increase their profit margin but to also pay off a crushingdebt load with interest. This is how the equity of the private equity firm instantly makes so muchreturn for its investors. Favorable tax laws such as the “carried interest” rule is the cherry on top. 
So, who pays for all of this? Captive ratepayers are the major source of revenue. Given that 74% of
the electrons from Allete go to large industrial users such as mines and paper mills who claim to runnarrow margins, much of this demand for corporate profit and debt service will fall on theresidential and commercial customers, in other words, Duluth. The ratepayers are the narrowshoulders upon which this need for revenue will fall.
The need for increased profits and debt repayment will also be bad for the climate. Several of the
purchasing entities have fossil fuel interests and nothing can be so efficiently rate based with a 10%rate of return than fossil fuel plants such as the proposed Nemadji Trail Energy Center in Superior.While California is putting up so much solar and storage that they cut their natural gas usage by 25%just last year, and Texas is moving even faster, Minnesota Power/Allete again missed an opportunityto leapfrog over fossil fuels and into renewables with storage in its last Integrated Resource Plan.Make no mistake about it, the needless increase in electricity rates will tragically result in lessbeneficial electrification of home heating, and transportation. Indeed, our family has been amazed athow our cheap solar electricity has replaced gasoline and soon natural gas, benefits which will beless likely to the ratepayers if this merger goes through.
This buyout is a solution in search of a problem. Allete has no documented inability to secure
capital. Investors love utilities precisely because of their captive ratepayers. Rather, we have acurrent management team at Allete which seems highly motivated to see this deal go through. Don’tlet them and don’t let us ratepayers down. Keep Allete under the microscope of transparency as a
publicly owned corporation.
Thank you,
Eric Enberg, MD

I am an employee of ALLETE, Inc. and I am submitting these comments in support of the proposed
sale of ALLETE to GIP and CPP Investments.
I believe this sale is an exciting opportunity for ALLETE to continue to provide safe, reliable, and
clean energy to the communities we serve. As someone who works within the company, I have seenfirsthand our commitment to our customers, our employees, and to building a sustainable energyfuture. 
This transaction brings greater access to capital, to allow ALLETE to invest more rapidly in renewable
energy, grid modernization, and infrastructure that will benefit Minnesotans and the broader region.From an employee perspective, GIP and CPP have expressed support for ALLETE’s current leadership,operations, and workforce, which provides reassurance that they recognize the strength and stabilityof ALLETE’s team.
As an employee of ALLETE for over 30 years, I have seen leadership consistently make decisions with

Sincerely,
Julie Fender

I am a community member residing in Minnesota Power territory and a customer of over 25 
years.  
I’m writing in strong support of the proposed acquisition of Alette by CPP and GIP . This transaction provides a clear and efficient path to meeting the state’s clean energy mandates —mandates set by the state itself, not the utility company. The proposal aligns 
with long -term sustainability goals and embraces modern technologies that are more 
reliable than many realize. These innovations are crucial for co mpliance and necessary to 
modernize our aging energy infrastructure.  
To form my opinion, I personally attended multiple in -person and virtual public hearings 
and listened to a wide range of perspectives. What became clear is that the most informed and experienced voices, especially those from labor, infrastructure, and busi ness 
sectors —overwhelmingly support this acquisition. There was a consistent and compelling 
case made that this deal is not only necessary but strategic, forward-thinking, and rooted in real -world needs.  
A key point raised at these hearings, and worth emphasizing is that rate increases are proposed by the utility and determined/approved by the Public Utilities Commission (PUC), not by ALLETE or any potential new ownership. This oversight remains unchanged regardless of the sale. There is a common misconception that this transaction would 
automatically lead to rate hikes, but in fact, the opposite is more likely true. Increasing 
rates are inevitable as time progresses to maintain the system and those costs c ontinually 
rise as time goes on. If the sale doesn’t proceed, higher rising rates are almost a certainty. 
This acquisition brings in capital investment that supports keeping costs down and enables critical infrastructure improvements.  
Some concerns have been raised about recent stock market volatility, but it’s important to 
note that those events occurred after the acquisition announcement and have no bearing 
on the fundamentals of the deal. Using market ﬂuctuations as a reason to oppo se this plan 
distracts from its actual merits and long -term beneﬁts.  
This acquisition will position ALLETE to modernize its systems, improve reliability, and continue delivering affordable, stable service. A well -capitalized, ﬁnancially stable 
company is better equipped to make the long -term investments our energy grid nee ds. 
Claims that the sale would reduce infrastructure investment are not supported by facts; if 
anything, the reverse is true. 
Workforce stability is another major reason to support this deal. The physical infrastructure 
and the people who maintain it remain essential, regardless of ownership. Multiple labor voices have emphasized that this transition supports job security and kee ps skilled union 
workers in place, people who are vital to the day -to-day operation of the utility. This is not 
about cutting jobs; it’s about strengthening the system and the workforce behind it.  
It’s also important to address misinformation that has been circulating. Some opponents 
have made unfounded claims about foreign control, the end of public oversight, or the abandonment of renewable projects. These claims have been directly and repeatedly 
corrected by experts, business leaders, and community members. The utility is not locally 
owned, and under the current proposal, it would remain under full regulatory oversight. Nothing about the deal removes the obligations or controls in place to ensure accountability and transparency.  
Of course, no decision is without risk, but fear of the unknown is not a reason to avoid progress. This is a structured, transparent, and well -thought -out plan that positions us for a 
stable, resilient energy future. If this deal doesn’t go through, we fac e the very real 
possibility of a less favorable outcome, such as a hostile takeover, with far less local input or oversight.  
This acquisition is about moving forward. It’s about building a grid that can withstand future challenges, meet climate goals, keep rates manageable, and ensure that skilled union workers remain at the heart of the energy system. I urge decision -makers to support this 
transition—for the future of our energy, our economy, and our communities.  
 
Eric Berube  
1863 County Rd 4 
Carlton, MN 55718

To the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,

BEFORE THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
COMMENTS OF DAWSON N. WEATHERS OPPOSING APPROV AL OF ALLETE, 
INC.’S PROPOSED ACQUISITION  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
To: Chair and Commissioners of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
 
I. Introduction  
As a concerned Minnesota citizen, I respectfully submit these comments in opposition to 
the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. (the parent company of Minnesota Power) by private 
equity interests led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and 
Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP,” now part of BlackRock) . This $6.2 billion transaction 
would transfer our region’s essential electric utility from a publicly traded company to a privately 
held consortium. Under Minnesota law, the Commission may approve such an acquisition only if 
it finds the transaction is “consistent with the public interest.”1 As explained below, this proposal 
fails that legal standard. The record developed in this docket , including testimony from the 
Minnesota Department of Commerce, the Office of the Attorney General, consumer advocates, 
environmental justice organizations, and even Minnesota Power’s largest industrial customers , 
demonstrates significant risks to ratepayers, local communities, and Minnesota’s clean energy 
goals, with no offsetting benefits that would satisfy the public interest requirement . I urge the 
Commission to deny approval of the acquisition.  
II. The Public Interest Standard and Burden of Proo f 
Minnesota’s public -interest standard demands more than just benefits to ALLETE’s 
shareholders or the acquiring entities ; it requires real, tangible benefits to the public (especially 
the utility’s customers) that outweigh all of the  harms . Under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, subd.  1, the 
Commission must withhold consent unless  convinced that a proposed utility takeover is 
 
1 Minn. Stat. §  216B.50, subd.  1 (2024) (requiring Commission approval for a public utility acquisition and directing 
that consent be given only if the transaction “is consistent with the public interest”) . In reaching a public -interest 
determination, the Commission must consider factors such as the reasonable value of the assets and the impacts on 
ratepayers and service . 
consistent with the public interest.2 The petitioners carry the burden of proving this consistency , 
yet in this case they have offered little more than speculative and unenforceable promises. As 
several parties have noted, the Commission cannot deem the acquisition to be in the public 
interest merely because it may serve ALLETE’s business interests .3 Instead, the Commission 
must consider the impacts on those who rely on Minnesota Power’s service , including 
households, small businesses, large industrial customers, and communities across northern 
Minnesota . 
Thus far, the petitioners’ primary assertion is that having two large equity investors will 
improve ALLETE’s access to capital for future investments (such as achieving Minnesota’s 
100% carbon -free by 2040 mandate).4 However, neither ALLETE nor its new owners have

would materially improve financing beyond what is possible under continued public ownership. 
To the contrary, as the Department of Commerce’s expert found, ALLETE may actually face a 
smaller pool of available capital and new constraints if it becomes privately held , it would be 
reliant on two owners (GIP and CPP) who must also tend to their other investments, rather than

concluded that ALLETE’s claims of capital -access benefits are overstated, and that no 
meaningful public -interest benefits have been demonstrated , only significant downsides, 
including the potential for higher costs to ratepayers.6 Simply put, the applicants have not met

III. Risks to Ratepayers: Higher Costs, Higher Risks, and Reduced Service  
a. Control Premium and Rates.   
A central concern is the large “control premium” being paid to ALLETE’s shareholders – 
a premium that captive ratepayers will receive no share of yet  may ultimately foot the bill for. 
GIP and CPP have agreed to pay approximately $6.2 billion ($67 per share) for ALLETE, which 
is between $393 million and $1.5 billion above the company’s estimated value absent the 
takeover .7 That windfall goes entirely to current shareholders. By contrast, ratepayers are being 
offered no comparable value or credit. In the typical utility acquisition, 100% of the control 
premium (the extra amount an acquirer pays to gain control ) flows to the target’s shareholders, 
while customers are left with at best token short -term concessions .8 Here, the buyers insist they 
“will not attempt to recover this premium from Minnesota Power customers.”9 Yet, 
economically, the new owners must recoup that premium (with a profit) from somewhere , and 
Minnesota Power accounts for 81% of ALLETE’s revenue . It defies reason to believe the 
acquiring funds will simply absorb a near -billion -dollar premium without eventually pressuring 
the utility’s earnings. Indeed, as observed in other merger cases, the premium reflects investors’ 
expectation of extra returns beyond what regulation typically allows , through tactics like higher 
leverage or cutting costs , none of which bode well for ratepayers.10 If GIP/CPP cannot extract 
 
in acquisition premium. See also  CUB, Action Alert: Submit Comments (Apr.  2025) (hereinafter “CUB Action 
Alert”), at  2 (noting expert estimates of a $393  million to $1.5  billion premium above ALLETE’s standalone value, a 
“windfall for ALLETE shareholders that the buyers will expect to recoup, with profits”) . 
7 Scott Hempling, Inconsistent with the Public Interest: FERC’ s Three Decades of Deference to Electricity 
Consolidation , 39 Energy L.J. 233, 294 –95 (2018) (observing that in a typical utility merger, “100% of the control 
premium —the value the acquirer places on control —goes to the target company’s shareholders,” whereas the 
customer benefits offered are much smaller and often temporary) . In other words, shareholders reap a windfall 
payment (“control premium”) for selling, but ratepayers – who are the ones funding the utility’s revenues – receive 
at best token benefits that are dwarfed by the shareholder gain . Hempling argues that this disproportionality fails the 
regulatory principle that benefits should go to those who create the value . Here, ALLETE’s shareholders would 
receive a substantial premium (approximately $67 per share, well above the pre -announcement market price) , while 
ratepayers are promised little more than business -as-usual service.

Experience warns that private equity owners “make back their investment” through 
aggressive measures. For example, after Upper Peninsula Power Company (UPPCO) in 
Michigan was acquired by a private equity firm, that utility’s rates were increased repeatedly, and 
UPPCO’s residential customers now pay among the highest electricity rates in the region .12 
Minnesota Power’s customers could face a similar trajectory of rising bills if GIP/BlackRock 
seek outsized returns. Even if direct rate increases are subject to Commission approval, there are 
other avenues to pass costs to customers , for instance, through higher authorized equity returns 
(via pressure to raise the allowed return on equity to attract capital) or by prioritizing capital 
projects (which earn a regulated profit) over maintenance (which does not).13 The Commission’s 
regulatory oversight would be the main check on such efforts, but it could be tested and pushed 
by owners determined to maximize their ROI.  
b. Leverage and Financial Risk.  
Private equity buyouts are often highly leveraged, saddling the acquired company with 
new debt. While the petitioners have not fully disclosed their financing plans, the Commission 
should be wary of debt -loading strategies that could drive up the utility’s financing costs. The 
Department’s analysis flagged a “significant risk” that the acquisition will lead to a higher cost of

disastrous outcome for captive ratepayers who rely on continuous service.16 
c. Cuts to Service and Local Investment.  
If the new owners find that regulated rates and profits are not keeping up with their 
expectations, they may respond by cutting costs in ways that harm service quality. Unlike 
publicly traded utilities, which are at least subject to market scrutiny and a broad shareholder 
base, private equity owners have strong incentives to slash “expenses” that do not directly yield 
profits. Unfortunately, those expenses often include critical operational areas like maintenance, 
reliability upgrades, customer service, and community programs . As CURE’s testimony 
observed, regulated utilities earn a return on capital investments (like new power plants) but not 
on operations and maintenance , meaning an owner fixated on high returns will see maintenance

IV. Governance and Oversight Concerns: Short -Term Ownership, Transparency, and 
Accountability  
a. Short Investment Horizon & Enforceability of Commitments.   
The proposed buyers are private investment funds with finite lifespans,  not traditional 
long-term utility owners. GIP’s chairman has frankly stated that they are “opportunistic sellers” 
and that “everything we own is for sale” once  the investment team decides it’s time to exit .18 
GIP’s typical holding period for investments is reportedly under 10 years .19 This raises a strong 
probability that Minnesota Power could be sold again in a few years,  churning ownership and 
throwing the utility’s direction into flux . Even if the present acquisition were somehow found to 
confer slight benefits, those could be fleeting , and the Commission (and the public) might have 
to go through another resource -intensive review for the next sale on the heels of this one . The 
possibility of a quick resale also undermines any promises made by the current buyers: 
commitments about local presence or future investments could be mooted by the next owner, 
who would not be bound by informal assurances made today.  
On that point , the petitioners have offered only short -term, non -enforceable 
commitments. For example, they pledged no immediate layoffs and to keep employee pay and 
benefits the same, but only for two years after closing.20 They likewise said the headquarters will 
remain in Duluth, but did not guarantee how long . Such promises, limited in scope and duration, 
provide little comfort to workers and communities. After two years, the new owners would be 
free to downsize staff or relocate operations , moves that could particularly impact northern

Minnesota’s economy and undermine service quality. More critically, these commitments are not 
enshrined as binding conditions in any regulatory approval (at least as the deal currently stands). 
They are essentially public -relations assurances. The Coalition of Utility Cities and labor 
intervenors have rightly noted that even pro -union statements from the buyers have been tepid 
and lack firm guarantees beyond the short term .21 In the absence of enforceable conditions in a 
Commission order, the Commission’s ability to hold the companies to their word is limited. The 
public interest is not served by a deal that relies on trust in private equity promises rather than 
legally enforceable protections.  
Furthermore, if the new owners become dissatisfied  (say the Commission rejects a rate 
increase or insists on cost disallowances ) they could decide to under -invest in the utility or flip it 
to another buyer, leaving Minnesota Power in limbo. As the Large Power Intervenors’ expert put 
it, this scenario would leave regulators and consumers “between a rock and a hard place”: either 
accept unsustainably large rate increases to satisfy the owners’ profit goals, or face the turmoil of 
an attempted sale of the utility to whoever will take it.22 Such instability is precisely what utility 
regulation is designed to avoid. It contradicts the “public interest” to subject a critical utility to a 
revolving door of profit -seeking owners with short horizons. By contrast, Minnesota’s tradition 
of utility oversight has favored long -term planning, stakeholder input (through IRPs, rate cases, 
etc.), and continuit y, all of which would be strained by rapid ownership turnover.  
b. Transparency and Reporting.  
A shift from public to private ownership would significantly reduce the transparency of 
Minnesota Power’s operations and finances. As a publicly traded company, ALLETE is currently 
subject to SEC reporting, investor disclosures, and broad scrutiny by analysts and shareholders. 
A privately held ALLETE would face no SEC reporting requirements, and information about its 
financial condition and strategy would largely disappear from public view . The Commission and 
stakeholders would be left with only the data provided through regulatory filings, which , while 
significant , may not capture the full picture as comprehensively as public filings do. The

Private equity firms are notoriously secretive; their investors demand confidentiality, and they 
are adept at structuring transactions in complex ways that can obscure true economics. This 
culture clashes with the ethos of a public utility, which should be accountable to the public.  
Alarmingly, even during this review process , Minnesota Power and its prospective 
owners have withheld important information from public scrutiny. Large portions of their filings 
– including details of their future business plans and even projections of future rate increases  – 
have been marked “Trade Secret,” accessible only to parties under non -disclosure agreements . In 
some instances, critical information was redacted as “privileged” without following proper 
procedures, prompting objections from the Attorney General’s Office and others .24 The 
Administrative Law Judge has already had to intervene, ordering the petitioners to disclose some 
of the improperly hidden information.25 Such behavior sets a bad tone for how the companies 
would engage with regulators and the public in the future. If GIP and BlackRock are reluctant to 
share information now, when they seek approval and must curry public favor, one can only 
imagine their opacity once the deal is done . Diminished transparency would weaken regulatory 
oversight, as the Commission might have to expend more effort (through audits, data requests, 
and enforcement actions) just to get basic information that is today available as a matter of 
course. This is a step backward in utility accountability.

The entry of BlackRock (the world’s largest asset manager) via its ownership of GIP 
introduces an unprecedented web of potential conflicts of interest . BlackRock and GIP 
collectively hold stakes in a n indescribably  vast array of companies , including companies that 
are customers of Minnesota Power, suppliers to the utility, or competitors in some respects . For

It is also worth noting questions raised about the character and integrity of the acquiring 
entities. During this proceeding, evidence emerged linking GIP’s leadership to troubling conduct 
in another company: SunPower Corporation, a solar firm in which GIP holds a major stake , faced 
an accounting scandal and SEC investigation after its independent auditor resigned over alleged 
financial misconduct. A senior GIP executive (who is a witness in this docket) sat on SunPower’s 
board and has been named in lawsuits concerning that company’s misstatements. In rebuttal 
testimony, that GIP executive offered little explanation or assurance regarding these issues.28 
This history gives pause about entrusting our public utility to this management. While tangential, 
it underscores a pattern: the private equity model often prioritizes aggressive growth and 
financial engineering, sometimes at the expense of transparency and ethics. Minnesota’s 
ratepayers deserve an owner whose commitment to the public service ethos of a utility is beyond 
reproach. Here, there is legitimate doubt on that front.  
V. Implications for Minnesota’s Clean Energy and Environmental Justice Goals  
This proposed acquisition also threatens to derail or delay Minnesota’s progress on clean 
energy and to undermine environmental justice commitments. Minnesota law now requires 
electric utilities to supply 100% carbon -free electricity by 2040  – an ambitious goal that will 
demand steady investment in renewable energy, grid modernization, and transition plans for 
legacy fossil assets. The Commission must consider whether the new owners would help or 
hinder these efforts. Petitioners argue that by providing “patient capital,” GIP and CPP will 
accelerate Minnesota Power’s transition to cleaner energy. However, their track record and 
incentives suggest otherwise .29 As noted, GIP/BlackRock seek high returns over relatively short 
horizons. Large, transformative clean -energy investments (like wind farms, solar arrays, or 
transmission expansions) often have payback periods measured in decades and require consistent 
policy support. If the new owners do not see quick profit in such projects, they may be less 
enthusiastic to pursue them aggressively – or might favor continued operation of carbon -

whether the transaction would make it harder to hold the utility to its climate obligations. A privately held Minnesota 
Power might be less responsive to public and political pressure on climate issues, since it will no longer face annual 
shareholder meetings or the same level of public scrutiny on ESG (environmental, social, governance) performance.  
intensive assets to maximize short -term cash flow. In fact, Minnesota Power’s recent Integrated 
Resource Plan filing (coming after  the acquisition announcement) raised eyebrows: the utility 
signaled interest in adding 1,100  MW of new natural gas generation and stepped back from prior 
commitments to fully retire coal plants without fossil replacements .30 This apparent pivot away 
from a faster coal -to-clean transition is troubling. It could indicate that anticipation of new profit -
driven ownership is already tilting Minnesota Power’s strategy toward fossil -fuel investments 
that guarantee returns, i nstead of prioritizing cheaper renewables and energy efficiency which 
benefit consumers and the climate.  
To be clear, the public interest standard encompasses more than just rates . It also includes 
service quality, reliability, and alignment with state policy objectives such as environmental 
protection and equity. Here, nearly every facet of the public interest could be adversely affected: 
higher bills, worse service, less accountability, and a utility less responsive to Minnesota’s clean 
energy vision.31 
VI. Conclusion: The Transaction is Not Consistent with the Public Interest  
After careful review of the evidence and arguments, the conclusion is inescapable: this 
private -equity buyout fails the public interest test of Minn. Stat. §  216B.50. The deal provides a 
substantial windfall to ALLETE’s shareholders and the acquiring investors, but imposes 
significant risks on Minnesota ratepayers and communities  without offsetting benefits. The 
Commission’s mandate is to safeguard the public interest, not to bless Wall Street transactions 
that place Minnesota’s energy future in the hands of distant investors with divergent goals. 
Indeed, the opposition to this acquisition spans the spectrum of stakeholders from state agencies 
charged with consumer and environmental protection, to industrial power customers concerned 
about cost and stability, to advocacy groups for low -income and rural communities. This broad

off” at the idea of a profit -driven firm owning the utility)  . Numerous members of the public have submitted 
comments echoing these fears – that a private, profit -maximizing owner will not prioritize Minnesota consumers or 
state policy goals. Public input is a factor the Commission may consider, especially as it reflects the on -the-ground 
perspective of those who will live with the consequences. Here, public sentiment has been strongly skeptical of the 
acquisition’s merits.  
consensus underscores that Minnesotans see little upside and unacceptable downside  in the 
proposed sale.  
The Commission should give great weight to the warnings of its expert agencies. The 
Department of Commerce flatly concluded that taking ALLETE private is unlikely to yield 
meaningful benefits and could cause harm in the form of higher rates. The Office of the Attorney 
General has been active in pressing for transparency and scrutinizing the deal’s claims, reflecting 
skepticism that the transaction serves the public. Even Minnesota Power’s largest industrial 
customers , who might be presumed to favor corporate flexibility , have opposed the acquisition, 
with their consultant testifying it would lead to “unsustainably large rate increases” and loss of 
control over the utility’s direction .32 When normally divergent interests (residential consumers, 
big industry, environmental advocates, labor, and government experts) all line up against a 
proposal, it speaks volumes. The only substantial support has come from the petitioners and 
certain labor groups, the latter of whom support it conditiona lly on hoped -for commitments to 
jobs, commitments that, as discussed, are limited and unenforceable, and in some cases have not 
been solidified. Tepid or conditional support cannot overcome the affirmative evidence of likely 
harm.  
In sum, approving this acquisition would transfer a vital public service to an 
ownership structure ill -suited to uphold the public interest . The deal carries too many red 
flags: a huge diversion of value to shareholders at customer expense, heightened financial and 
operational risks, diminished regulatory insight, and misalignment with Minnesota’s policy 
priorities. Minnesota law does not compel the Commission to approve such a transaction, and in 
fact empowers it to reject proposals that do not affirmatively satisfy the public interest standard. 
This is a textbook case for denial.  
For these reasons, I urge the Commission to find that the proposed acquisition of 
ALLETE by GIP/BlackRock and CPP is not consistent with the public interest and to deny 
consent for the transaction. By doing so, the Commission will protect Minnesota ratepayers from 
unwarranted risks, preserve accountability for our public utility, and send a clear message that 
our state will not compromise the public interest for private gain. Minnesota Power can and 
should continue to pursue the capital and innovation needed for our clean energy future without

sacrificing local transparency, regulatory oversight, and consumer protections. The public 
interest is best served by keeping Minnesota Power’s obligations firmly anchored in Minnesota, 
under owners and a corporate structure that put the public good, not private equity profits, first.
